awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Search for the Epigenomic Mechanisms of Paternal Inheritance of Aggression in Social Honeybees
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Central State University seeks to determine the epigenetic modifications and epigenomic architecture connecting aggressive behavior of honeybees to their sociogenome.

To investigate the potential imprinting mechanisms via parental inheritance, the project will focus on the quantification analysis of epigenetic marks in the brain of Africanized and European honey bees. The use of modern epitranscriptomic and genomic approaches will reveal the molecular regulation of behavioral epigenomics. These studies will provide new insights and the first evidence of how epigenetic marks regulate or link to the process of transcription, gene regulation, or molecular evolution. A new field of behavioral epigenetics and epigenomics will also be developed using social honey bees as a model system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the epigenetic mechanisms of RNA methylation in the social behavior of honeybees. Particular research interest is on the M6A modifications in the RNAs molecular. It represented a cutting-edge new area of research (Insect RNA methylation) that was conducted at Central State University, the sole public HBCU in the State of Ohio with over 95% under-represented minority undergraduates in STEM. Our study focused on the eusocial honeybees (Apis mellifera).

This study has shed light on the research knowledge of the RNA methylation of m6A and long non-coding RNAs in social honeybees on how patrigenes and matrigenes influence the gene expression of offspring. The sequencing results revealed the parent-specific transcriptomic profiles in offspring workers and furthermore identified parent-specific and allele-specific m6A RNA methylation modifications. There is not much knowledge about the parent-specific genes such as their expression or epigenetic modifications underlying the behavior of aggression. We studied the genes from specific parent-of-origins in modulating aggression in worker bees through a reciprocal-cross design and Oxford Nanopore direct RNA sequencing. We detected increased paternal and maternal allele-biased transcription in aggressive compared to non-aggressive bees, and higher paternal allele-biased transcription overall. In addition, we detected more alternative splicing and unique long non-coding RNAs related to aggression from our results. We have published our results in BMC Genomics (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s12864-023-09411-4), and 4 student presentations at branch and national conference of ESA. Based on this research, we have submitted 3 new NSF grant proposals.

This project tremendously impacts the basic research and sciences of social insects, including behavioral ecology, evolution, genetics, and epigenetics.  It impacts life science in entomology, evolution, ecology, genetics, genomics, and physiology.  It has helped to connect basic research with undergraduate students out of the classroom setting. The project had a broader impact on the STEM majors of HBCU at Central State University, and students’ career and professional development.

Modified by: Hongmei Li-Byarlay
